dsiter.iterator

Interface IDatasetIterator

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.AutoCloseable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ArrayIterator, CacheIterator, DirectoryListIterator, FilterIterator, FirstIterator, LastIterator, RangeIterator, RenameIterator, SkipIterator, SkipWhileIterator, StrideIterator, TakeIterator, TakeWhileIterator, ZipIterator

    public interface IDatasetIterator
extends java.lang.AutoCloseable

    • Method Detail

      • tryMoveNext

        boolean tryMoveNext()
             throws java.lang.Exception
        Attempt to move the iterator's cursor.

        Some implementations will be able to implement this method lazily; for example an ArrayIterator may simply update a pointer or an index without actually constructing anything. Other implementations will need to do more work to determine whether or not another Row is available.

        Calling tryMoveNext() may change the value of getCurrentRow(), even if tryMoveNext() returns false. If tryMoveNext() returns false, the value returned from getCurrentRow() is not guaranteed to be valid. Similarly, because most iterator implementations reuse Row objects, the same caveats apply to Row objects that have been saved off from previous calls to getCurrentRow(). If another class requires a Row instance that doesn't mutate between calls to tryMoveNext(), it is responsible for creating its own copy of that Row (e.g. via RowCopier)

        Returns:
        true if the cursor was successfully moved to the next item, or false if there are no more items to be iterated over.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Implementation specific

      • getCurrentRow

        Row getCurrentRow()
           throws java.lang.Exception
        Return the current Row.

        In much the same way that tryMoveNext() will be lazy for some implementations, getCurrentRow() may be comparatively expensive, if it must do all the work of creating a Row.

        Calling getCurrentRow() more than once per call to tryMoveNext() should be valid for all implementations (it should return an identical Row every time, perhaps even the same instance). However, since getCurrentRow() may be expensive for many implementations, this behavior is not recommended.

        Returns:
        Row The current Row
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Implementation specific

      • tryGetLength

        long tryGetLength()
        Return the iterator's length, if known, or -1 if the length is not known. Regardless, this will not cause any change in the state of the iterator (i.e. no calls to tryMoveNext() will be made)
        Returns:
        The length of the iterator, or -1 if unknown

      • getColumnDescriptors

        ColumnDescriptor[] getColumnDescriptors()
        Return descriptions of all columns supported by this iterator.

        The Rows returned by a given iterator may contain more values than are described by the returned ColumnDescriptors. This is a simple and efficient way to delete a column; simply remove the ColumnDescriptor that describes that column and all other iterators and writers should treat that value as if it doesn't exist.

        Note: the order of the returned column desciptors may matter for many applications (e.g. most writers will write them in that order).

        Returns:
        This iterator's ColumnDescriptors

      • getColumnDescriptor

        default ColumnDescriptor getColumnDescriptor(java.lang.String name)
        Look up a ColumnDescriptor by name

        The default implementation of this method simply iterates over getColumnDescriptors() and returns the first column whose name matches. Implementations of this interface may override this method to provide a more efficient lookup mechanism (e.g. a HashMap) if they so desire.

        Parameters:
        name - The name of the column to be described
        Returns:
        A ColumnDescriptor describing the named column, or null if no such column exists

      • computeShape

        default RowShape computeShape()
        Compute the RowShape of this iterators columns by counting how many of each type there are.
        Returns:
        a RowShape instance describing the shape of the Rows returned by this iterator.
        See Also:
        IPipe, StdPipes

      • pipe

        default IDatasetIterator pipe(IPipe pipe)
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Attach a pipe to the current iterator
        Parameters:
        pipe - The pipe to be attached to this iterator
        Returns:
        An iterator that represents this iterator with the pipe attached
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Rarely happens, but since some iterators apply pipes by repeatedly calling tryMoveNext, this method could throw anything that that method could throw.

      • tryAbsorb

        boolean tryAbsorb(IPipe pipe)
           throws java.lang.Exception
        Attempt to 'absorb' a pipe into the iterator. For example, an iterator may have a way to efficiently filter certain kinds of rows and, if so, it may choose to absorb some FilterPipe instances instead of allowing them to behave in their normal, potentially inefficient, manner (FilterPipes must create a Row instance for every possible Row so that they can inspect them and decide if they must be filtered out or not. There are sometimes much more efficient ways to filter out rows that don't involve reading them at all). An important example is datasets that interface with some sort of database system or large sorted file system: when they see certain kinds of IPipes they may be able to reduce their workload by incorporating the pipe into the base query (for databases) or by only reading the relevant subset of the files (for filesystem-based datasets). It's important to note that absorbing a pipe necessarily modifies an iterator in some way. Attempting to absorb a pipe may modify the iterator even if tryAbsorb returns false; the pipe is said to be partially absorbed. When tryAbsorb returns true this means that the pipe has been fully absorbed and should be discarded. A partially absorbed pipe should still be applied as if it wasn't absorbed, but the iterator may still have made some optimizations under the hood (indeed; the caller has no way to tell whether a pipe was partially absorbed or not absorbed at all and the two situations should be treated identically). As an example of why a partially applied pipe might be useful, imagine a dataset that is a series of CSV files. The rows in the files are ordered by time, as are the files. If a filter("time>2016-01-01") pipe is applied, the dataset iterator will be able to exclude all files that are strictly before 2016-01-01. However, the first file may include a mix of rows that are before 2016-01-01 and rows that are after. The iterator has managed to exclude a potentially large portion of rows that are guaranteed not to match the filter but not all of them, so the filter still needs to be applied to the remaining rows. If 2016-01-01 happens to be an exact boundary between CSV files then perhaps the iterator will be able to fully apply the FilterPipe - depends on how optimized that particular implementation is.
        Parameters:
        pipe - The pipe that the iterator should try to absorb
        Returns:
        True, if the pipe was completely absorbed (and should be discarded), else false.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Rarely happens, but since some iterators apply pipes by repeatedly calling tryMoveNext, this method could throw anything that that method could throw.
